column5: description
A microbial phenotype describing characteristic growth with respect to environmental temperature (e.g., preference classes such as psychrophilic, mesophilic, thermophilic, hyperthermophilic).
A microbial oxygen preference phenotype in which growth occurs in the presence of molecular oxygen (O₂), typically using O₂ as the terminal electron acceptor.
A microbial oxygen preference phenotype in which growth occurs in the absence of molecular oxygen (O₂).
A microbial oxygen preference phenotype that requires molecular oxygen (O₂) at concentrations lower than atmospheric.
A microbial oxygen preference phenotype in which growth can occur with or without molecular oxygen (O₂).
A microbial oxygen preference phenotype that requires molecular oxygen (O₂) for growth.
A microbial oxygen preference phenotype in which molecular oxygen (O₂) inhibits or prevents growth.
A microbial oxygen preference phenotype in which growth can occur without oxygen but is capable of aerobic growth.
A microbial oxygen preference phenotype that does not use O₂ for growth but tolerates its presence.
A microbial oxygen preference phenotype that tolerates low levels of molecular oxygen (O₂) without requiring it.
A microbial oxygen preference phenotype reported generically as “facultative” (no direction specified); kept as its own class to avoid collapsing specific subclasses.
A microbial oxygen preference phenotype reported as “strictly anaerobic” in Madin; modeled distinctly and placed under obligately anaerobic.
A temperature preference phenotype in which growth is favored at low temperatures, typically near or below ~15 °C.
A temperature preference phenotype in which growth is favored at intermediate temperatures, typically ~20–45 °C.
A temperature preference phenotype in which growth is favored at elevated temperatures, typically ≥45 °C.
A temperature preference phenotype in which growth is favored at very high temperatures, typically ≥80 °C.
A temperature tolerance phenotype in which growth can occur at low temperatures without an obligate low-temperature preference.
A temperature tolerance phenotype in which growth can occur at elevated temperatures without an obligate high-temperature preference.
An observation specializing temperature observation for optimum temperature data.
An observation specializing temperature observation for general growth temperature data.
An observation specializing temperature observation for growth temperature range data.
An observation specializing temperature observation for tolerance breadth (delta) data.
An observation specializing temperature observation for culture temperature data (e.g., reported culture conditions).
An observation record about a microbe’s growth with respect to temperature, potentially including point, minimum, and maximum values, comments, and negativity (no growth).
